TextView.android:text: Non-Mutually Exclusive Events
In this lesson, we will learn how to find the probability of non-mutually exclusive events.
Introduction to lesson
Click on the video to start watching a lecture on the probability of non-mutually exclusive events
Video Source: https://youtu.be/UKuCyADXAlg?si=3xXizE_JR5ssnsaq5

1. rolling a pair of dice showing doubles or a sum of 12.
2. drawing a face card or a jack of clubs from an ordinary deck of cards.
3. rolling an even number or a prime number.
4. spinning a 6 or an even number on a roulette with numbers from 1- 10.
5. drawing a red card or a diamond from an ordinary deck of cards.
Let us visualize the non-mutually exclusive events using Venn Diagram. Observe that the circles representing each have an overlap.

P(A) is the probability of getting a number 3
P(B) is the probability of getting an odd number
P(A and B) is the probability of a number 3 and an odd number

A die has 6 faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. There exist one (1) number 3, three (3) odd numbers, and one (1) number which is both 3 and an odd number.

Thus,
The probability of die showing a number 3 or odd number is 1/2.

In a standard deck of 52 cards, there exists 26 red cards, 12 face cards. Also, there are 6 cards which are both red cards and face cards and these are jack, queen, and king of diamonds, and jack, queen, and king of hearts.
The probability of drawing a red card or a face card is 8/13.
